awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Cold War Convergence: The Making of a Chile-California Scientific Network
awd_abstract_narration:
Mediterranean-type ecosystems (MTEs) represent two percent of terrestrial landmass but possess a plant diversity that is second only to that of the wet tropics. MTE regions—centered between thirty degrees and forty degrees north or south of the equator, and characterized by cool, wet winters and warm, sunny summers—demonstrate remarkable physical similarities, but efforts to study them collectively are relatively new. In 1971, biologists hailing from the world’s five MTE regions convened their first meeting. They collaboratively tested the evolutionary theory of convergence, the notion that like environments shape like life forms. In the process, they established a global scientific network based on common concern for these analogous landscapes. Now, this decentralized group of researchers represents a key body of expertise around urbanization, water scarcity, wildfires, and more. This project seeks to unpack and explain the connective success of a group of far-flung scientific individuals. Despite having no legal charter or institutional affiliation, the MTE network has endured—seemingly on the basis of strong personal and intellectual relationships. Findings from this project will offer insights into how science functions across national boundaries, and will be of interest to policy makers, scientists, and environmentalists of many stripes.

Research focuses upon scientific contact between Chile and California, the two MTE regions often deemed most alike. The project draws upon archival research and new oral history content from interviews with key historical actors to address three related questions: What scientific and theoretical context influenced the working relationships of these scientists? Within the Cold War context, how did broad U.S. foreign policies designed to contain communism influence person-to-person relationships? And did these relationships translate into management decisions—did they influence conservation techniques, protected area boundaries, fire management policies, or in other ways shape the landscapes of California and Chile?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For millennia, the gentle weather patterns of the world’s mediterranean climate regions have made life easier for humans. The dry, sunny summers and cool, wet winters have nurtured agricultural output and multitudinous cities. But away from major human development, the temperate weather correlates with extraordinary levels of biodiversity. Ecologists that have focused on mediterranean-type ecosystems (MTEs) have noticed something more: the plants look and behave very similar to each other. These likenesses might not be surprising if the various species were closely related, but they have not had a chance to mingle—indeed, the world’s five MTE regions are about as far-flung as might be possible, located in Chile, California, Australia, South Africa, and the countries rimming the Mediterranean Sea. How to explain these similarities between geographically distant species?

The intellectual curiosity behind this question launched the informal collaboration that I call the MTE Network. In the late 1960s, a pair of scientists based in Chile and California, respectively, teamed up to compare their landscapes. Harold (Hal) Mooney of the University of California and Francesco di Castri of the University of Chile wanted to probe the theory of convergent evolution, the concept that like environments shape like species. To this end, they scouted out analogous field sites—virtual twins in separate hemispheres—in which they could comparatively examine the geology, weather, plant communities, birds, lizards, and more. To run the multi-year study, di Castri and Mooney recruited dozens of scientists, graduate students, and technicians from universities in Chile and California—functionally creating a new constituency of global mediterranean specialists.

This research project sought, and continues to seek, to explain the lasting durability and fruitfulness of the MTE Network. The network coalesces most materially every three to five years at the Mediterranean Ecosystem Conference, always hosted in one of the five MTE regions. The informal nature of the network, along with the small number of meeting participants (between 100 and 200 attendees), misrepresents the group’s historic influence within international environmental governance and climate science. Although the network indubitably incorporates biologists from all five MTE regions, the relationship between California and Chile is central. The story of Mooney, di Castri, and the ongoing exchange of expertise between Chile and California highlights the twentieth-century confluence of Cold War-era science funding, the growing influence of the field of ecology, and a dash of scientist charisma.

The funding made available through the Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant enabled the Co-PI to access critical primary source material. Research trips facilitated access to archival collections housed in various cities throughout Chile and California, visitation to the historic field research sites near Santiago and San Diego, and informal interviews and formal oral history sessions with local scientists. Furthermore, the grant supported professional transcription of ten oral histories, an important component of an archive-ready oral history collection.
